segments.text: very much opposed to.
I'm opposed to public policy trying to direct research towards specific relevant goals.
Not because the goals aren't worthy, but because I think that we're not smart enough to know how to do that properly.
I'm quite a fan of basic research, which then when you then look at and find out what results from basic research can be turned into focused strategic results at a later date.
I think a good example, just a personal anecdote from people I've known, Ron Prinn at MIT was a student when I was there working with John Lewis.
And he worked on the photochemistry of the Jupiter atmosphere.
And he was tremendously excited, as we all were, about the things emerging, about the new knowledge of the chemistry of the solar nebula and the atmosphere of the planets.

And Ron has since become one of the leaders in the details of the photochemistry of the Earth's atmosphere as well, including the destruction of ozone and the chemistry in the atmosphere leading to those types of things.
You could never have started out a program in your wildest dreams that said, I want somebody to go study the chemistry of Jupiter's clouds in order to solve the ozone layer problem.
That is not the way science works.
And unfortunately, a lot of the people in Washington are just totally misguided in this sense, mostly because of background.
They're mostly lawyers.
That is not the way you set up a scientific program to develop the things you need for public policy.

And I think as scientists it's our duty to, even though it's nice to sell a program and try to get lots of bucks for particular relevancy, to try to step back a little bit and educate and provide good advice to the government that we need the broad-based research
in order to have the successful focused research.

A lot's been made of our, this is an area that I'm not personally connected with, but a lot's been made of our interactions with the Japanese over the years and the fact that they have exploited a lot of microchip technology and things like that.
A lot of that basic research, if you go back, I believe you will find was done here.
And it wasn't that anybody wasn't focused properly here.
It's that the people didn't take
and develop the industrial government relationships to use that basic science for economic ends as well here as they did in Japan.

I think if you started off trying to find the next thing in that area and focus all of your research on that, you're probably missing what will really be the big payoff because you don't know what it is.
It's out there someplace in basic research.
Here's the penultimate question, and it's wildly different.
At the beginning of this century, planetary astronomy was a respected part, a large part of the general field of astronomy.
People like Henry Norris Russell wrote papers on the upper atmosphere and clouds of Venus.
By the end of World War II, it was essentially dead.
Who killed planetary astronomy?
Well, that was before my time, of course.
It's before everybody's time, so I have to ask.
My, well, you might find a few still.
Gee, isn't, what's his name?
Vanderholtz is still around, isn't he?
Yeah.
I guess my perspective on that, and it comes from what study I've done of the history of science, is that my guess is that Percival Lowell killed it off.
Gerard de Bacalure, that was...
That was what he said, just two words.
And then there's also the comment that, really, when you think about it, there wasn't much people could do with the photographic plates that they had to take spectra.
Photometry was no good.
And they kind of ran up against a brick wall in learning anything physically about the planets.
Yeah.

I also think perhaps dead is not as, if you look at the overall field of planetary science as opposed to specifically going to the telescope and making physical observations of the planets, it was not that dead.
There was still celestial mechanics going on and research into orbital theory and things of that sort.
In fact, going into the early ages, parts of the space age, if you look at kind of a broader base thing.

But specifically with respect to telescopic work that our brother astronomers would regard as astronomy, I think that the taint of getting involved with the types of social images that became associated with Percival Lowell and the little green men on Mars and canals and so forth drove off a lot of people.
And I think your point about technology is an important one.
I think that in addition to a few key individuals like Gerard Kuiper getting involved in planetary astronomy, the resurgence of planetary astronomy had a lot to do with technology.
that evolved past the photographic plate, past World War II particularly, photoelectric and infrared sensors and the rest of the electronic revolution basically.
We've seen the recent demise of the Galileo, I mean of the Mars Observer space probe as it attempted to enter orbit around Mars.
There's also an Air Force probe called Clementine, which is supposed to do all sorts of things that are a ridiculously small amount of money.
And I have heard that there is some thought being given to abolishing NASA, making it the National Aeronautics Administration, and letting the Air Force do the stuff.
Would you work for the Air Force under those circumstances?
I'd continue to try to do my science, depending on who was funding it.

I had a lot of colleagues in the early days that had a very successful relationship with the Office of Naval Research, which had a history of funding very fundamental research into communications theory, radar, and radio propagation, for instance, from which they derived a lot of practical benefits, but they put few constraints on it in those days.
I think that could work.
You could imagine, I guess the problem is you can imagine any number of ways in which public policy and funding could be conducted.
If you want my opinion about NASA with all of its faults now versus
trying to turn over these things to the remains of the Star Wars program in the Air Force, I'd say nuts.
I think that wouldn't work at all.
You talk about Clementine being cheap.
All that's cheap is this particular piece of hardware that one is trying to deal with.
The investment to produce that thing, whatever it is, was huge.
That investment isn't there on that side of the government either at the moment for future things.
That's going to be tough to prove that to Congress.
They're just going to look at the bottom line.
The reason I mention that is that before there wasn't an NSA, the Air Force poured an enormous amount of money into stuff.
Kuiper's big four volumes, that was Air Force funded.
My graduate studies were all funded by the Air Force.

They gave a lot of money to places like McDonnell Douglas and Louise Young worked there under Gil Ploss, and there were a lot of infrared spots for John Strong, and Bill Sinton got a lot of Air Force money.
And the Air Force was ready, willing, and able to just keep going.
They didn't want an NASA.
You know what?
NACA, keep doing what it's doing, and we'll take care of space.
I was fundamentally a policy decision made by the Eisenhower administration to make civilian space as our response to Sputnik.
And I think it's served the country well.
It's not to say that one couldn't imagine another structure or even that another structure might not be desirable now.
But at the moment...

I think one of the keys to what you just said is bucks, and I think that the parts of the DOD that would like to get involved in this at the moment are doing so not because there's big bucks there, but because they're desperately trying to find a reason for existence for some of the parts that have wound down as a result of the Cold War going away.
What we ought to do is schedule another session for the whole horrid story of the great Saturn's rings affair with Kuiper and Crookshank and the MIT crew.
But I would just say, since I was talking about ion volcanism, I thought I might just share with you a little bit of my perspective

personal history in terms of the time that Voyager actually discovered the volcanic, volcanically driven plumes on Io, if you will, because I don't think it's generally appreciated that we, in effect, did ourselves in in a very clever way and prevented the discovery of the plumes on Io in real time.
And
To understand this requires a little bit of knowledge about the way the real-time imaging systems worked at JPL.
The images come in to the DSN and then went over to the, at that time, the image processing laboratory for more detailed work.
That's where all the computer magic, if you will, ended up getting produced on the pictures, put on disks so we could observe them on monitors and so forth.
with the usual stretches.
People are used to the concept of stretches and so forth, and in essence re-exposing the images and looking at different intensity levels.

During the Voyager mission at Jupiter, for the first time, we had the option of putting in a little bit of image processing up front right after the data came in from the DSN so that we could display in real time on monitors around the laboratory processed images, not raw images.
And for Io in particular, and the satellites, we couldn't guarantee that all the exposures would be just right to come out.
In other words, if we had put up raw images, they would have looked all right, but they would have looked washed out.
At Jupiter, too.
So we developed a number of these real-time algorithms that we could put in there so the images on the TV tubes would look nice to people as they were coming in.
The nature of these algorithms were to take the faintest

few percent of the image and the brightest few percent of the image and throw it away and and expand the contrast of what remained called an auto ends in stretch because you only have so much available and if you want to expand the middle range you've got to get rid of the extreme
Now, of course, we weren't actually throwing away in the data.
That was going onto tapes and going on in for later analysis.

But if you think about what an auto ends in stretch, i.e., throwing away the bottom few percent of intensity levels and stretching the picture does for Io, it is the best anti-volcanic plume filter you could possibly imagine.
The plumes are not very bright.
The plumes were not very bright.
So as a result of that, it turned out that the plumes were crashingly easy to observe in raw images, even though the surface of Io wouldn't have been well exposed in those cases.
So in effect,
by making the real-time pictures more accessible to the public, making them look better on the monitors, we denied all of us the real-time discovery of the plumes.
It's sort of ironic.
The press room would have been, you know, it would have had the guy from the New York Times and Jonathan Eberhardt and people like that would have been the discoverers of the plumes.
They would have seen them first.
They were very easy to find.
And it was interesting.
The way they were actually found, as you probably know, was by an optical navigation engineer looking at a highly stretched picture.
And the reason we hadn't looked at any raw pictures by that time was everybody was exhausted after the Jupiter encounter.
Everybody went to bed and slept for 48 hours immediately afterwards.

And we came back in, I think it was the following Monday morning, I've forgotten the exact time sequence, and we started, our duty on the imaging team was, okay, now let's look at each picture, make sure we know what's in it, and we can kind of, you know, catalog what's there so we can start the analysis process.
So Joe Verwerk and several of us sat down at one of the terminals and started going through the pictures.

we'd heard kind of whisperings around the uh around the hallways that something funny was there and brad wouldn't tell us what it was what had happened was linda had linda marvita had found this thing on this highly stretched overexposed image of the taken for optical navigation purposes and she'd finally taken that to brad and said look you know something funny here we can't explain and he'd figured out it was probably a volcanic
We were looking for volcanic effects at that time as a result of Peale et al.
's prediction of volcanic effects on Io.
It came out just before, and also because of the way the surface looked.
But nobody at that point had imagined we might actually see active volcanism.

In fact, there was a predilection not to jump in that direction because the Mars people with Viking orbiter had been skunked several times by people making false claims to having seen active volcanism.
So at any rate, we kind of knew something was up.
We knew something was up, and there were people scurrying around, and Brad had his door closed and so forth.
So I said, let's sit down and take a look at the pictures.
So we started going through the raw pictures with Joe sitting there.
I'd forgotten who else was standing around.
And Joe pulled up a picture, which I think probably turned out to be what we now call Prometheus, with this little mushroom sticking out the side of the planet.
And Joe looked at it and says, hey, what the hell is this?
And we all looked at it and said, it must be a volcano going off by a dam.
Brad walked out about that time, and we pulled him over and said, Brad, is this what we're not supposed to know about or talk about?
He looked at it and says, get that off the screen.
Because these things, of course, could be seen in other places.
Then he looked at it and says, what?
That's another one.
So the rest of the day was spent hunting plumes and cataloging all the plumes.
But in retrospect, it's really ironic that by applying our neat image processing techniques early on, we delayed that discovery by about a week, as it turned out, in terms of when the data showed up.
Although I don't know whether or not I would have been awake to actually try to do anything with them if we discovered them during the encounter.
You mentioned the affair of Saturn's rings.
I've already interviewed Dale Cruikshank, and he was rather short on that.
Could you kind of add a few personal notes on that?
Well, that was when I was a postdoc at MIT, and the offices in the lab right around where I was, Clark Chapman and Carl Pilcher were both working.

Carl was getting geared up to do infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy on satellites and rings, and ultimately was one of the people that was involved in the final pegging down of the identification of water ice on the Galilean satellites.
But what occurred at the time of the Saturn's ring spectra was that there was a Sky and Telescope article published with a very recent spectrum that Dale had taken, I believe.
I've forgotten with what instrument.
Compared with a solar-type star spectrum in the usual classical astronomical way.
And they differed.
And the place of maximum difference was a wavelength that looked like it might be associated with an ammonia absorption.

And so there was this Sky and Telescope article, which in effect was the first publication of the spectrum, which is a little bit irregular anyway, which identified this as ammonia absorptions in Saturn's rings.
That's what it was.
What happened, I think, probably was motivated by Carl's beginning his thesis work on worrying about a similar type spectra for the Galilean satellites.
They looked at this stuff and they said, well, I can't really make heads or tails out of this.
We've got to back up.
This isn't a ratio spectra.
What they were doing was actually comparing the little wiggly spectra, looking for the maximum difference.
Now, if you think about it, the difference is not what you want.
A lot of astronomers get used to dealing with differences as the right quantity, because if you look at differences in magnitude, it's a ratio of intensities.
Only these were intensities, and they were looking at the point of maximum difference.
What Clark and Carl did was took and Xeroxed the spectrum up and digitized it.
I've forgotten exactly how, and took a ratio.
The ratio spectrum showed
dips in a different place than the different spectrum did, if you will.
And they looked at that and said, that doesn't look like ammonia.
And they dug out some recent work at that time by Hugh Keefer, who had measured the spectrum of various ices.
And he says, that's just water.
It looks just like Keefer's water spectrum.
Now, what happened after that, I was kind of an outside observer on all of this, if you will.
That was my position as well.
I knew everybody involved, but I
And, you know, Carl and Clark sort of asked my opinion about what sorts of things ought to be done.
Clark was a close friend of Dale Kirkshank's.
And my memory is what happened was he called up Dale and said, Hey, Dale, you know, that ain't ammonia, it's water.
And he explained it, and Dale says, By God, you're right, you know, or something similar.
And so then they went into one of the first DPS meetings was coming up right after that.
And they went into a big soul searching about what ought to be done in these cases.
Interestingly enough, there was a classic case of the sentient bands on Mars where a similar thing had happened.
And what ended up happening in that case was all of the various parties got together and published a paper with the correct interpretation, basically.
Well, there were also a few fiascos, like taking some of the Mariner spacecraft and finding hydrochloric acid and hydrochloric acid on Mars.
Yes.
Before my time.
And what is it, helium on where?
Venus or Mars or something like that.
Yeah.
So at any rate, what I remember happening was that Clark called up Dale, and what he suggested was a collaboration.
He says, look, you know, we didn't take these data.
This is your data, Dale, you know.
But I think this is the right interpretation, and, you know, we'd like to get some credit for it.
So they, in essence, proposed a collaborative paper with taking the specter and laying it out.
And this is hearsay evidence now is that Dale took this proposal
took this proposal to Kuiper and got a rather emphatic no back on it.

Kuiper's position was apparently something along the lines of his laboratory had a program in this area and they would have stumbled onto this very shortly anyway, and these interlopers from MIT could go, you know, fly a kite.
If it's not a true story, it should have been because it's quite characteristic.
Quite characteristic.
At any rate, what I do know has happened is Dale ultimately came back to Dale, to Clark and Carl, and said, you know, you're right, but I...
but I can't be a co-author with you on the paper.
Kuiper nixed that.

And so the end result was that the paper that actually correctly identified water ice as a major constituent of the rings of Saturn based on Dale Kirkshank's spectrum never had Kirkshank's name on it, which is a shame in terms of the history of science, although they gave every possible acknowledgement to where the spectrum came from and referenced the Sky and Telescope article.
It's an example of, I think, some of the negative aspects of the kind of autocratic way in which some of the old-time planetary astronomers ran their lab.
There's very little flexibility in some cases, and it wasn't many years after that that Dale left LPL for a very successful career out in Hawaii.
Well, of course, in those early days, people like Kuiper
They were acting in the condition of the old-time observatory heads who were God Almighty.
Dr.
Professor, there is only one professor in the department.
Well, I never had the guts to call him Gerard.
Fred Whipple is the only person I know.
Well, I'll tell you, I didn't have that type of relationship with Quaper either, but Bruce Murray got him on my thesis committee.
I should say, I've forgotten exactly what they called it at JPL.
When we defended our dissertation, there was a committee that usually tried to involve a few outside scientists.
And since my thesis was on the Galilean satellites, Bruce Dragoon and Kuiper into sitting on my committee.
Now, Caltech, these things were not the Spanish Inquisition type of things that they are in some departments.
That came earlier in the orals.
If you passed your orals and put together a respectable dissertation, they didn't let you defend your dissertation unless it was ready to go.
So these things were generally relatively gentlemanly type affairs.
But Jim Westfall was another member of my committee.
And during the course of my discussion, he started baiting me about the issue of the sizes of the satellites and what their albedos were.
At this time, there were no really accurate measurements of the diameters of the satellites.

They're all about one arc second to one and a half arc seconds in size, as seen from the Earth, and notoriously hard to measure, going back to early measurements using a stellar interferometer by Michelson himself, who didn't get the right answer, by the way, for reasons I still don't understand.

But Kuiper had made quite a deal for some years right around that time of making these very, very accurate, he claimed very, very precise discometer measurements, comparing discs under similar illumination in an eyepiece with what he was seeing under very good conditions, and was making what a lot of the more physical astronomers regarded as somewhat exaggerated claims to the precision with which he could measure diameters this way.
You tried that with Pluto, too, as well.
Yes, all the small objects.
And, you know, I mean, it was a valiant effort.
It was one way to attack the problem.
But it was regarded as highly unphysical by the Caltech types.
And I had very carefully hedged my bets in my dissertation on this by plotting everything that had diameter in it with a full range of errors in all diameter measurements.
Albedos and densities and so forth were big errors.
big blobs with error bars and all of my stuff, because I didn't want to touch the issue of what was the right numbers, because I knew we didn't have them.
But Westfall began baiting me a bit, trying to get me to say that Kuiper's numbers were all hogwash.
And I said, well, you know, what numbers did you use here?
How do you possibly measure something to that accuracy?
And I continued to dance around this with Gerard sitting there.
for the innocent bystander when the cops shoot him out with the bank robbers.
And I have something very pleasant to say about Kuiper as a result.
About midway through this, and Westfall, as you know, can get very aggressive on these types of things.
About midway through this little discussion, Kuiper sat back and said, well, those were my measurements, and they don't really affect the results of this gentleman's dissertation.
Let's move on.
So I have a debt to Gerard Kuiper on that score.
This is war story time.
You're talking about the attitudes of traditional astronomers.
And my very first experience could have turned me off entirely on this whole thing.
Very soon after I started thinking I was going to be doing observations for part of my thesis work, Bruce had some time scheduled on the 60-inch at Mount Wilson.
And he said, you go up there with the equipment.
Use it.
I can't use it tonight.
I'd never been up there in my life.
So he told me how to get up there, how to get in the gate, how to get to the monastery, and when dinner was, and told me I'd better get up there in time for dinner.
He didn't give me any background or any warning or anything.
Both Palomar and Mount Wilson were still very tradition-bound back in 66, 67.
And as it turned out, there was only one other observer on the mountain, Olin Egan, I believe, who was on the 100-inch.
And, of course, the 100-inch observer was the king.
He sat at the end of the table and rang the little bell for getting the food and so forth.
And here I was, this first-year graduate student trying to figure out what to do at the famous Mount Wilson Observatory,
And here's this gruff old astronomer, Ola Negan, sitting up there.
And this was in the midst of the Vietnam War, of course, and there was some stuff going on.
I'd forgotten exactly what that was.
They did have a TV up there.
And I said, let's turn on the TV and find out what's happening with the news.
And Ola Negan looked at me and he says, we make our own news up here.
I said, yes, sir.
That was my introduction to the traditional astronomers.
So continue.
Okay.

The identification of the Vesta spectrum proceeded very rapidly because we had in hand at that time the preprint from McCord and Adams, which they just sent us up from where they were working on the Apollo samples, a couple of figures.
And what they were doing was comparing various lunar spectra with various other things.
And some of the things that had been proposed as having come from the moon or being like the moon, in fact, were the Eucritic
meteorites.

So there was a spectrum sitting in front of us of Nuevo Laredo and a whole bunch of lunar spectrum, and when Jay Elias brought in the plot of the data from the Vesta stuff from the previous month's run or whatever it was, it laid out with this huge absorption band in it, and I looked at it, and I looked at this preprint and figure that McCord had given me, and I said, by God, it's a basaltic achondrite.
And I called up Tom and said, it's basaltic achondrite, Tom.
You know, it's what it is.
Then we proceeded to have a couple of weeks of very detailed work going back and forth as to whether we really thought it was a basaltic achondrite or not.
It looks too obvious.
It looked too obvious.
And the other thing was that it turned out that there was another mineral that actually looked very similar to this, a pure mineral, is enstatite.
that has an absorption feature that actually seemed to match a little closer.
And Tom was going for, no, it's got to be Instatite.
It can't really be this Eucrite-Pyroxene ratio type of thing.
And it was John Lewis that finally got him off that after a little bit of acrimony.
I don't know just how much.
Lewis pointed out to him that, yes, Instatite had an absorption band there, but no meteoritic Instatite had any iron in it.
The Instatite achondrites don't have any iron content.
And so, yeah, you know, an enstatite with iron in it has a band in the right place, but that isn't what you get out in meteorites.
So we ended up resolving it in favor of the, of Eucrites being the best match to the thing.
But it was really the most obvious
spectral identification that I've ever seen.
It sat there and sitting there on the old Cal Comp plotter and comparing it with the Xerox of Tom's spectra, comparing lunar stuff to Nuevo Laredo, it was like a dry lab.
Well, you should write a letter.
